title: Case Study: Mrs. Jeanette K. and Progressive Knee Osteoarthritis
clinical_history: Mrs. Jeanette K. is a 67-year-old retired librarian who presents with a gradual onset of right knee pain over the past 6 years, progressively worsening in the last 12 months. She reports stiffness in the morning lasting about 20 minutes, which eases with gentle movement. The pain is aggravated by walking long distances (more than one block), descending stairs, and rising from a low chair. She also experiences increased discomfort after periods of gardening or shopping. She notices crepitus with knee movement and mild swelling after heavy use, with no locking but occasional feelings of instability. She denies nocturnal pain unless she had an active day. There is no history of trauma, but she reports a history of being overweight (BMI 32) and a previous diagnosis of prediabetes.

nprs.affected_area: right quadriceps (secondary muscle fatigue and aching after activity)

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged walking (>10 minutes), standing >15 minutes, descending stairs, rising from a low surface, cold/damp weather, gardening, shopping trips
picture: [use an anatomical diagram highlighting the medial knee joint and adjacent quadriceps]
easing_factors: Short rest periods, gentle range of motion exercises, heat pack to knee, low-dose paracetamol, elevation after activity, swimming/aquatic exercise
past_history: Gradual increase in body weight over the last 20 years; mild, quickly resolving right knee sprain 8 years ago (no persistent injury), no prior joint surgeries or significant trauma.
medical_history: Prediabetes diagnosed 5 years ago; hypertension well-controlled with medication; mild hypercholesterolemia.
medications: Paracetamol 500 mg as required (1-2/day), Lisinopril 10mg daily, Simvastatin 20mg nightly
personal_history: Married, lives with spouse in a single-story home. Retired for 2 years, previously sedentary occupation. Hobbies include gardening, knitting, and volunteering at the local library. Limited formal exercise; recently started aquatic classes at the community pool.
imaging: Recent bilateral knee radiograph reveals medial joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation on the right knee consistent with moderate osteoarthritis. No evidence of acute fracture or inflammatory arthropathy.
